analysis.root_cause: Tuna-9 topology cannot support [[4,2,2]] detection code. Both XXXX and ZZZZ stabilizers require degree-4 ancilla connectivity (CNOT between ancilla and all 4 data qubits). Tuna-9 max degree is 3 (qubits q1 and q2). Even optimal mapping (ax=q1 connected to q0,q3,q4; az=q2 connected to q0,q4,q5) leaves each stabilizer with 1 non-adjacent data qubit requiring 3-hop SWAP routing.

optimal_mapping_analysis.xxxx_missing: q1-q5 (3 hops via q4-q2 or q0-q2)
optimal_mapping_analysis.zzzz_missing: q3-q2 (3 hops via q1-q0 or q1-q4)

emulator_comparison.gap_reason: Circuit rejected by hardware compiler due to non-adjacent CNOT pairs

analysis.interpretation: [[4,2,2]] detection code FAILED on Tuna-9. All circuit variants rejected by hardware -- the 6-qubit detection code requires degree-4 ancilla connectivity that exceeds Tuna-9's tree topology (max degree 3). SWAP routing would add 6+ CNOTs per stabilizer, making the circuit prohibitively deep (~22+ CNOTs vs 11 native). This is a fundamental hardware topology constraint, not a noise issue. The emulator achieves 100% detection rate with the same circuits. Recommendation: use 3-qubit repetition code (already demonstrated at 93.2% syndrome accuracy on Tuna-9) or wait for higher-connectivity hardware.
